bibl.title: Letter, Lyman C. Draper in Madison, Wis., to J.G.M. Ramsey in Knoxville, Tenn. 1875 Aug. 3
bibl.note: Lyman C. Draper, Corresponding Secretary, State Historical Society of Wisconsin, Madison, Wis., wrote to J.G.M. Ramsey, Knoxville, Tenn on August 3, 1875. He requested that Dr. Ramsey find out and forward specific information to him on early Southern Presbyterians in regards to how they treated Saturdays. He referred to the book he is writing and to ex-President Johnson's death. He thought highly of Johnson. J.G.M. Ramsey attached a letter to the end of Draper's letter. He sent it to Rev. Dr. Park. Ramsey asked Park to help him answer Draper's letter. Ramsey was not aware of Presbyterians ever using Saturdays in preparation of the Sabbath. He mentioned he knew that four days were devoted to the communion service and Friday as a fast in olden times. He thought there was preparation for the communion service. He asked if this was a practice of the whole church or just in North Carolina and Tennessee.

div.p: I have one point I wish to have your opinion on -- in common with others --- it is

To what extent did the early Presbyterians of the South make use of Saturday as a preparation day for Sunday -- whether merely in temporal matters, or whether this day was in whole a part used as a religious preparation, by meeting with or without a pastor?
I don't see anything in Foote & other Presbyterian writers on this point.
My associate, Mr. Butterfield, takes hold finely -- & we are digging away on our first
book -- on Border Forays & Adventures, simply first, because the book we said it wd. pay best, & we needed something for bread and butter.
I am sorry to hear of Ex-President Johnson's death. I once spent a pleasant hour with him. He was thoroughly honest --- that goes a great ways in these, or indeed any times.

Help me to answer this letter of Hon. L. C. Draper. I did not know before that Presbyterians ever used Saturday as in preparation for the Sabbath -- on the other hand in the olden times when the communion was to be administered, four days were devoted to that service but Friday was then observed as a Fast days & was oficially observed as preparatory to the sacredness of acommunion occasion -- Am I correct in this? & was this the unmonied of bon whole church or only of North Carolina & Tennessee Presbyterians? Please return this letter & your observations on the subject matter of it.
